verses.text: After this, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them, and he took control of Metheg-ammah from the hand of the Philistines.
verses.comment: Metheg-ammah likely refers to Gath and its surrounding territory.

verses.text: He also defeated Moab, and he measured them with a line, making them lie down on the ground. He measured out two lines to be put to death and one full line to be spared. So the Moabites became servants to David and paid tribute.
verses.comment: The measuring with a line is literal; some were executed, others spared.

verses.text: David also defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he went to restore his rule at the River Euphrates.
verses.comment: Zobah is an Aramean kingdom north of Israel.

verses.text: David captured from him one thousand chariots, seven hundred charioteers, and twenty thousand foot soldiers. He hamstrung all the chariot horses, but left enough horses for one hundred chariots.
verses.comment: Different manuscripts mention different numbers for charioteers and horsemen; 'seven hundred charioteers' here follows Masoretic Text.

verses.text: When the Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, David struck down twenty-two thousand Aramean men.
verses.comment: Arameans are also called Syrians in older translations.

verses.text: Then David set garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and the Arameans became servants to David and paid tribute. The LORD gave victory to David wherever he went.
David took the shields of gold that were carried by Hadadezer's servants and brought them to Jerusalem.
From Betah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, King David took a great quantity of bronze.
verses.comment: Berothai may be the same as Chun in Chronicles; location uncertain.

verses.text: When Toi king of Hamath heard that David had defeated the whole army of Hadadezer,
verses.comment: Hamath is north of Israel, near the Orontes River.

verses.text: Toi sent his son Joram to King David to greet him and congratulate him for fighting and defeating Hadadezer, since Hadadezer had often fought against Toi. And Joram brought articles of silver, gold, and bronze.
verses.comment: Joram called 'Hadoram' in Chronicles; both are variant spellings.

verses.text: King David dedicated these also to the LORD, together with the silver and gold that he had dedicated from all the nations he had subdued:
verses.comment: David set aside spoil from victories as offerings to the LORD.

verses.text: from Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, Amalek, and from the spoil of Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
verses.comment: Spoils gathered from many nations subdued by David.

verses.text: David made a name for himself when he returned from striking down eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
verses.comment: The number ('eighteen thousand') matches 1 Chron. 18:12. Sometimes 'Arameans' ('Syrians') are listed in place of 'Edomites' in other manuscripts.

verses.text: He set garrisons throughout all Edom, and all the Edomites became David's servants. The LORD gave victory to David wherever he went.
So David reigned over all Israel, and David administered justice and righteousness to all his people.
verses.comment: David is pictured as the ideal king: fair and just.

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army, and Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder.
verses.comment: Joab as commander; Jehoshaphat kept records and official documents.

verses.text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelech son of Abiathar were priests, and Seraiah was secretary.
verses.comment: Dual priests and the chief scribe are listed.

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites, and David's sons were priests.
verses.comment: Cherethites and Pelethites were David's elite guards. David's sons served as priests (sometimes translated as officials).
